Most importantly, we stress our commitment to ensuring a safe operation for our employees, our visitors, and our community.

All of the technical documents referenced above is listed in the Process Safety Information portion of the PSM Manual/Files at the facility. 

Chemical specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDS) which are kept on site at the facility for all employees to read. For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperatures, level and composition in the operator procedures manual. The facility maintains the process within these limits by using process controls, written procedures, monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems.

The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings. This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to safety features in the process to assure they are not compromised. 

C. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

WES has a comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with the PSM covered process. This program systematically exams for po

tential hazards and puts controls in place to manage hazards. The PHAs conducted included HAZOPS and What If Checklists methodologies and included a team of WES employees who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The team is tasked to identify, evaluate and make recommendations to management of the potential hazards associated with the process. If possible, the team affects the changes necessary to mitigate the hazards identified.  If the mitigation required is more involved or cannot be mitigated by the team, their findings are forwarded to WES Management for resolution. The approved mitigation options in response to the PHA team's findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

The facility periodically updates and revalidates the PHA to assure that the hazards identified have been properly mitigated and that new hazards or previously unknown hazards can be dealt with. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.

D. Operating Procedures

WES maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered process that address primary operations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practice and manufacturers. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current accurate by employees and management. The procedures are maintained current and accurate, revising them as necessary by employee's suggestion, compliance audit, PHA's, Good Engineering practice, Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and Management of Change.

Covered process Operating Procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to sa

In addition, WES will evaluate the Contractor safety program and performance during the selection of a Contractor. Facility personnel periodically monitor Contractor performance with regard to their safety obligations.

G. Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

WES conducts a PSSR for any facility modification that requires a change in the Process Safety Information or procedure. The purpose of the PSSR is to see that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and services as quality assurance verification that the Accident Prevention Program requirements are properly implemented.

H. Mechanical Integrity

WES has established practices and procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating, pressure containing and emergency shutdown equipment. The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:
1. Conducting training
2. Developing written procedures
3. Performing inspections and tests
4. Correcting identified deficiencies
5. Applying quality assurance measures

Maintenance personnel receive training on:
1. Overview of the process
2. Safety and Health hazards
3. Applicable maintenance procedures based on manufacturer's recommendations and operational experience
4. Emergency Response Plan
5. Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner

Written procedures provide that work is performed in a consistent manner and serve as a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help v

fely perform their job task and maintain the covered process unit operating within its safe limits.

E. Training

WES has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the covered process. New employees receive basic training in process operations at this facility.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. A performance review and written test specific to the facility operations is administered and must be successfully completed during this training period. After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the Operating Procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years, or more frequently upon request or need. All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.

F. Contractors

WES uses Contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some Contractors work on or near covered process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that Contractors: 

1. Perform their work in a safe manner
2. Have the appropriate knowledge and skills to perform the necessary tasks
3. Are aware of the hazards in the workplace - both the ones they bring to the worksite and the ones that exist at the facility
4. Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency
5. Understand and follow site safety rules
6. Inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work
7. Know and understand the Stop Work policy at the facility

This is accomplished by providing Contractors with: 

1. A process overview of the facil

If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service. A Management of Change team will review the use of equipment and determine what action is necessary.

An integral part of the Mechanical Integrity Program is quality assurance. WES incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps to determine that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

I. Safe Work Practices

WES has safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, EPA, Industrial Standards and Good Engineering Practice in place to help provide employee, public and process safety.

J. Management of Change (MOC)

WES has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all Reported Covered Processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology and procedures be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. 

Changes are reviewed to:
1. Determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards
2. Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the proposed change
3. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. All operations and maintenance personnel are trained on the changes before they are implemented.

K. Incident Investigation

WES promptly investigates all incidents related to a covered process that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team do

cuments its findings, develops recommendations to prevent future occurrences, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years.

L. Compliance Audits

At least every 3 years a Compliance Audit addressing all OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineering Practices are conducted by a corporate audit team, which is made up of operations, maintenance, engineering and HSE personnel. This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed. Final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained. 

M. Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The following is a description of existing features applicable to prevention of accidental release of regulated substances in this facility.

Universal Prevention Activities

WES accident release prevention and response policies are applied to all RMP-covered processes. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

N. Specialized Safety Features

Site specific detection and control equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the plant to:

1. Contain/control a release

2. Quickly detect a release, and

3. Reduce the consequences of an RMP-regulated substance release


The following type of safety features are used in the covered process:

Release Containment/Control

1. Process relief valves

2. Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process

3. Automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and automatically op

erate all automatic valves to their fail-safe position, keeping all incoming gas out of the plant

4. Curbing or diking to contain liquids releases

5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, safety switches, etc)


Release Mitigation

1. Trained emergency response personnel

2. Personal protective equipment

3. Fire Extinguishers


O. Five-Year Accident History

Ramsey Gas Plant has had one RMP-regulated substance release during the past five years.


P. Emergency Response Program Information

Ramsey Gas Plant is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The plant maintains a written Emergency Response Plan, which was developed in accordance with OSHA PSM requirements and is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, if a release occurs.

Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate. WES has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff's Office). This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition, WES conducts periodic emergency drills and annual refresher training for plant personnel.


Western Midstream's management is committed to the following:

-Preventing accidents;

-Training our employees in correct response procedures in the event of an accident;

-Participating in community emergency preparedness;

-Addressing any citizen concerns by fully explaining potential hazards

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Western Midstream (WES) owns and operates a natural gas processing facility known as Ramsey Gas Plant, in Reeves County, Texas. The plant was purchased from Nuevo Midstream, LLC late in 2014.  The plant is designed to process natural gas and recover liquid product from natural gas by physical separation and cryogenic means. Petroleum condensates are transported onward to another facility for processing.

WES has acommitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Ramsey Gas Plant is located near Orla, Texas and operates a variety of processes to produce the following petroleum products from raw natural gas:

1. Natural Gas Liquid Product (Y-Grade, Ethane-plus)
2. Condensate 

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

A. Employee Participation
Employees of the Ramsey Plant are required to participate in all facets of Process Safety Management and accident prevention as follows:

1. Updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information
2. Performing necessary calculations for PSM and RMP
3. Maintaining good engineering practices
4. Participating as a member of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) team

In addition, all employees have full access to all information pertaining to accident prevention.
